The auxiliary རེད་ is similar to the verb “to be” in English. It can function either as an autonomous verb (or “copula”), or as the auxiliary of another verb. This is comparable to the English “to be” or the French “être,” which are both copulas (e.g., “he is mad,” “il est fou”) and auxi­liaries (e.g., “he is working,” “il est arrivé”). Likewise, in the following Tibetan sentences རེད་ is a copula in the first and an auxiliary (associated with the nominalizer པ་) in the second:

  • ཁོང་སྨྱོན་པ་རེད། “He is crazy.”
  • ཁོང་ཕེབས་པ་རེད། “He came.” (Literally: “He is come.”)

As a copula, རེད་ expresses the nature or the essential quality of the subject. Note that རེད་ “to be” is used to express people’s age, just as in English.

The verb རེད་ is generally pronounced ré (with a more open vowel) in sentences that have an interrogative pronoun. However, the Tibetan spelling remains unaffected.

Questions are constructed by using the final interrogative particle པས་:

  • རེད་པས། “Is it?”
  • མ་རེད་པས། “Isn’t it?”

Like other auxiliaries, the verb རེད་ and its negation མ་རེད་ are used to signify “yes” and “no.” They may be preceded by the polite marker ལགས་.
